abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings are as follows:
            Project outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is substantial, Bank
            performance is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            satisfactory. Lessons learned from this project included the
            following: 1) The quality of supervision of this project was
            one that the standard supervision budget does not ordinarily
            support-the real level of effort was much higher and
            achieved through cross-subsidies from other tasks. 2) More
            support should have been provided during preparation,
            especially since the project was substantially more complex
            than previous Bank-financed health projects in the country
            and experience with a technical assistance- and
            reform-intensive project was lacking. 3) The Project
            succeeded in both meeting its objectives and receiving the
            full support of government while doing so; and these in turn
            laid a strong foundation for future scale-up efforts, both
            in terms of a powerful demonstration effect and of
            government buy-in to the reform process. 4) Change
            management, public relations, and communications are
            critical. 5) Pilot activities should be designed and
            implemented with a view to scaling-up from the outset. 6)
            There were lost opportunities for monitoring and evaluation.
            7) The use of relatively large, multi-year
            single-institution contracts was a sensible strategy for a
            new borrower with complex TA requirements and limited
            capacity to manage multiple consultants or contracts. The
            effectiveness of these efforts is only called into question
            the linkages between the agencies that received support and
            the broader health system context was fragile. 8) Provider
            training and quality assurance activities provided a strong
            foundation for developing continuing medical education.
